title: Pelosi fast-tracks bipartisan resolution to 'oppose' Trump's Turkey policy
text:
A bipartisan pair of lawmakers is developing legislation that would limit the ability of Turkish President Recep Erdogan to travel to the U.S., while House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is fast-tracking legislation that would oppose the Trump administration's Syria policy moves.

South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham, a Trump ally who has blasted the president's decision to remove troops and effectively allow a withering Turkish assault across the border into Syria, is among those working on the Senate legislation.

He and Maryland Democratic Sen. Chris Van Hollen are working on a resolution that would limit the ability of top Turkish officials, including President Recep Erdoğan, to travel to the U.S. It also would hit the military and energy sector of the NATO ally, the Hill reported.

Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and other top officials would have their ability to visit the U.S. limited under a bipartisan Senate resolution to protest Turkey's attack on Kurdish forces in Syria

It was not immediately clear how the proposed resolution might affect what Erdogan has said is a planned trip to Washington in the first part of November to meet with Trump. He told reporters about the trip in Ankara last week, Reuters reported.

Pelosi spoke with Graham Monday, as she prepares to have the House move rapidly with its own legislation, amid bipartisan condemnation of President Trump's decision to acknowledge Turkey's planned invasion in advance and remove U.S. troops. Turkey followed with an immediate invasion, while U.S. Kurdish allies responded by making a deal with Russia-backed Syria.

Pelosi tweeted Monday: 'Pleased to have a conversation with Senator @LindseyGrahamSC this morning. Our first order of business was to agree that we must have a bipartisan, bicameral joint resolution to overturn the President’s dangerous decision in Syria immediately,' she wrote.

She backed off the language of moving to 'overturn' the policy, and wrote that the resolution coming to the floor would 'oppose' the policy.

'Next, we must put together the strongest bipartisan, bicameral sanctions package similar to the bipartisan bill the House is advancing,' she wrote in another tweet.

'As we find ourselves in a situation where the President gave a green light to the Turks to bomb and effectively unleashed ISIS, we must have a stronger sanctions package than what the White House is suggesting,' Pelosi wrote.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House will take action this week on its own resolution dealing with Turkey

A House resolution opposes President Trump's latest policy moves in Turkey and Syria

Trump ally Sen. Lindsey Graham is working on the resolution

Senator Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) has teamed with Graham on the effort

This picture taken on October 15, 2019 shows smoke rising from the Syrian town of Ras al-Ain, from the Turkish side of the border at Ceylanpinar district in Sanliurfa, on the first week of Turkey's military operation against Kurdish forces

Pelosi spoke with Graham about a bipartisan, bicameral resolution

Pelosi wants stronger sanctions than those in an executive order signed by Trump

Graham has called the new Syria policy a 'disaster in the making.'

In a statement Pelosi said Trump 'has unleashed an escalation of chaos and insecurity in Syria. His announcement of a package of sanctions against Turkey falls very short of reversing that humanitarian disaster.'

'This week we will proceed with bipartisan, bicameral action to oppose this irresponsible decision,' she added.

The House resolution coming to the floor is titled: 'Opposing the decision to end certain United States efforts to prevent Turkish military operations against Syrian Kurdish forces in Northeast Syria.' It references a sudden White House announcement state said: 'Turkey will soon be moving forward with its long-planned operation into Northern Syria' and that 'United States Armed Forces will not support or be involved in the operation, and United States forces … will no longer be in the immediate area.'

The White House announced its own sanctions on Monday, while also halting talks on a $100 billion trade deal with Turkey. An executive order by President Trump declares Turkey's cross-border invasion 'undermines the campaign to defeat the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, endangers civilians, and further threatens to undermine the peace, security, and stability in the region.'

After giving what Turkey took as a green light to invade, Trump said he is prepared to 'destroy Turkey's economy' to halt the military offensive.
description: Bipartisan Senate legislation would limit travel by top Turkish officials including President Erdogan and hit military and energy sectors, while House legislation is advancing.
authors: Deputy U.S. Political Editor For Dailymail.Com
